Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multiscale Investigation and Mimicry of Naturally-Occurring Ultra-High Performance Composite Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project investigates the structure-property relationship of extremely tough biological composites through a combined computational/experimental methodology. It will particularly focus on the synergetic role of geometry and length scales by investigating specific features such as hierarchy, periodicity and patterning in the microstructure and interfaces observed in some extraordinarily strong natural materials. The research approach consists of: i) exploring, identifying and quantifying the contributions of the individual multiscale deformation mechanisms of the natural composites using a multiscale computational approach aided by specially designed experiments, ii) a biomimetic effort following a combined computational and prototype modeling approach that employs advanced 3D printing techniques, and iii) developing design guidelines, validated later by constructing materials that incorporate the most important microstructural features identified in (i) and (ii). Achieving these insights will uncover design rules to develop impact and damage tolerant materials.

There is a strong demand for new paradigms of design and development of advanced high-performance structural materials with high strength and durability, low in cost and renewable with novel combinations of properties and qualities. We will study biological composite materials that can achieve high toughness without sacrificing stiffness and strength by control of nano- and microstructural features that significantly improve the mechanical performance of otherwise brittle materials. Additionally, this research will provide the rational mechanics framework for the development of high-performance and multifunctional materials for a wide range of technologically relevant applications in the areas of energy, defense, homeland security, civil, industrial safety, medicine and automotive industry. The educational component is closely integrated with the research, to inspire and attract students to the STEM field by its multidisciplinary nature. Undergraduate and graduate students will be mentored in an interdisciplinary setting. Additionally, the integration between research and education will improve engineering undergraduate and graduate education by including components of biology in material related courses through the infusion of cyberlearning tools and hands-on experience. The PI will introduce a new multidisciplinary course entitled "Materials and structures inspired by Nature for infrastructure applications and beyond" with special guest lecturers from Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Materials Science and other engineering disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a strong demand for new paradigms of design and development of advanced high-performance structural low-mass/cost materials with high strength and toughness with environmentally friendly materials that not always have the best mechanical properties. As such, one of the current challenges in materials engineering is the design of novel architected materials that can offer better trade-offs in terms of mechanical performance. The field of bioinspired architected materials has been gaining popularity in the last few years by providing evidence that geometrical control of material placement, enabled by advanced manufacturing techniques, can indeed lead to improved properties, and in some cases, to novel properties not attained before with conventional methods. On the other hand, we know that some key naturally-occurring materials have extraordinary mechanical properties and are highly efficient at providing protection and other functionalities, while using only the minimum amount of mechanically modest materials that are available in the environment. There is a plethora of aspects that make these materials ideal source of inspiration for the design of new engineering materials (e.g., self-assembly, conditions at which synthesis takes place, multi-functionality, hierarchical structure, fluid transport, self-healing, extreme mechanical properties, etc.). A closer look to their inner structures reveals complexity and architecture. The goal of this CAREER project was to devise how nature employs these strategies, investigating their fundamental mechanical behavior and contributing with the necessary knowledge and tools for the design and fabrication of cost-effective, environmentally friendly ultra-high performance multifunctional materials inspired by their naturally occurring counterparts. 

The main findings in this project are related to how biomimicry allowed us to elucidate what critical aspects and characteristics of these complex architectures are responsible for the remarkable mechanical properties exhibited by these biological materials. In particular, this project focused on the extraordinary  capabilities of helicoidal or Bouligand architectures found in the exoskeleton of certain arthropods such as lobsters, crabs, mantis shrimp, and even beetles. For instance, starting from careful examination of the experimental observations done on the actual biological materials, followed by the formulation of hypothesis and theoretical models, we were able to develop computational models to  demonstrate that one of the main toughening mechanisms in Bouligand composites comes from crack twisting (i.e., cracks follow the orientation of the fibers) that makes the material becomes tougher as a crack tries to twist, in effect halting its progress.  These mechanisms provide local hardening of the material, which in turns, promotes delocalization and spread of damage which leads to extensive energy dissipation and improved toughness. We also found that these architectures are natural metamaterials that are efficient at filtering damaging shearing waves. These mechanisms and many others allowed us to explain why these particular architectures are very tough compared with their constituents. The implications of the findings in these results is that these concepts can be now be used in the fabrication of new composites materials.  During the last few years, there have been attempts by companies and other groups to use this in composite and other 3D printed materials (e.g., such as concrete, polymers and ceramics).  At the same time, the educational goal was to attract and inspire undergraduate and graduate students to become the next generation of ?recruiters? in STEM.  This was achieved by several outreach activities done in different venues done by the PI and his graduate and undergraduate students.  The educational component was closely integrated with the research. This project influenced the undergraduate and graduate civil engineering program at Purdue University by integrating aspects of the work into the classroom.
